Description: Intact pottery jug with a convex sided body and a slightly flared neck, finished with a rounded, external rim. A single handle runs from the rim to the shoulder.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Naukratis, Well A (= Hogarth site 36)
Curator's comments: Excavated from a well by Hogarth in 1899 and said to be given to Bulak Museum in Cairo, although this object was not found registered in Cairo, Egyptian Museum (Edgar 1905, 123-5, Fig.3). The collection of pottery from this well was dated (rather generally and not correctly) by von Bissing to 525-323BC (Edgar 1905, 124-5). Edgar claimed this was a common Egyptian type.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (IB.051)
Exhibition history: Thought to be stored in Cairo, Egyptian Museum
